unnormalised: ## Taxing My Brain (and Wallet): A Humorous Look at Indian Tax Law
normalised: ## Taxing My Brain (and Wallet): A Humorous Look at Indian Tax Law

unnormalised: Alright folks, let's talk tax. Not exactly the stuff of stand-up comedy, I know. But trust me, navigating Indian tax law can be so convoluted, so baffling, it's almost… funny. Almost. Think of it as a really long, poorly written Bollywood script, where everyone's trying to figure out who owes whom what.
normalised: Alright folks, let's talk tax. Not exactly the stuff of stand-up comedy, I know. But trust me, navigating Indian tax law can be so convoluted, so baffling, it's almost… funny. Almost. Think of it as a really long, poorly written Bollywood script, where everyone's trying to figure out who owes whom what.

unnormalised: First off, let’s address the elephant in the room, or rather, the GST on the samosa. Why, oh why, do we need to pay GST on delicious, golden-fried goodness? Is it not enough that our waistlines are already taxed by these delightful treats? The govt. clearly wants a share of our happiness. The GST on that chai might also be around 5%.
normalised: First off, let’s address the elephant in the room, or rather, the G-S-T on the samosa. Why, oh why, do we need to pay G-S-T on delicious, golden-fried goodness? Is it not enough that our waistlines are already taxed by these delightful treats? The government clearly wants a share of our happiness. The G-S-T on that chai might also be around five percent.

unnormalised: Then there’s the whole IT return filing process. Every year, millions of us scramble to gather Form 16s, receipts, and assorted documentation that looks suspiciously like ancient scrolls. It's a national sport, akin to cricket, only with more anxiety and less cheering. And let's not forget the joy of deciphering the various sections and sub-sections. Section 80C? Section 54? It’s like learning a whole new language, one that only tax professionals and insomniacs truly understand. I swear, I spent 3 hrs last year figuring out what to do.

Section fifty four? It’s like learning a whole new language, one that only tax professionals and insomniacs truly understand. I swear, I spent three hours last year figuring out what to do.

unnormalised: And just when you think you've got it all figured out, the government decides to "simplify" the tax code. "Simplify," of course, means "make it even more complicated, but pretend it's easier." This usually involves introducing new forms, new rules, and new ways to accidentally end up owing the IT dept. a small fortune. Remember when they said "taxation will be so simple, a child can do it"? I think even my 10 yr old nephew would struggle!

unnormalised: Don’t even get me started on the notices from the tax department. Receiving one of those is like getting a wedding invitation from your ex. You know it's not going to be a pleasant experience. The language is always so formal, so intimidating, you'd think you've committed a crime against humanity. "Dear Assessee, It has come to our attention..." *Cue dramatic music*.

unnormalised: But hey, at least we have options. We can hire a CA (chartered accountant) to navigate the maze for us. Think of them as our tax sherpas, guiding us safely through the treacherous terrain of deductions and exemptions. Just remember to factor in their fees – because, of course, you have to pay tax on that too. My CA, Mr. Sharma, charged me Rs. 5000 this year.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the sheer creativity of Indian tax planning. From investing in ELSS funds to claiming HRA, we're a nation of tax-saving ninjas, constantly searching for loopholes and grey areas. It's like a game of chess, except the stakes are much higher, and the opponent is the entire Indian government. The last date to file is 31/07.

unnormalised: So, there you have it – a humorous (or at least, an attempt at humorous) look at Indian tax law. It's complicated, it's confusing, and it can sometimes feel like you're being robbed blind. But hey, at least it provides endless fodder for jokes, right? Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go figure out if I can claim a deduction for the therapy I need after dealing with all this. Wish me luck!
